title: Bear-u-lele /  The Ukulele with a Bear Head!

description.text:
Bear-u-lele
=====
The next iteration of my playable ukulele is the Bear-u-lele. Show off the unique abilities of a 3D printer with this fun to play instrument.
Check our a video and hear what it sounds like here:
http://youtu.be/N875O4PB0ws
Body

Print the body from the "Playable Ukulele". The neck will slide in just like the original neck.
Neck

The neck needs slight support for the top part of the mouth. Other than that, I haven't needed any other supports for the new neck.
Paws

The paws print without supports. I used a cooling column to give the claws time to cool between layers.
Assembly
I printed in PLA for the one shown.  I super glued the neck into the body.  Installed the guitar tuning machines.  Added purchased soprano ukulele strings.

title: Vac-line pick & place tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This device is designed to assist a repetitive pick-and-place operation in a confined space. It is worn on the right index finger, with a vacuum line attached to the fitting at the back (see detail image below).
Normally air can enter both through the pickup end and through the side port. The side port is located adjacent to the right thumb's normal rest position so that the thumb can easily cover the hole. If a flat object is placed in contact with the pickup end and the side port is covered, the interior is at reduced air pressure and the object is picked up (if not too heavy). When the thumb is removed from the port, air can enter and the object is released.
In order to improve conformal contact at the pickup end, I designed it such that a skeletal framework only is printed, into which I cured some silicone rubber to form a gasket (see close-up image). The casting stand is designed to hold the device in the correct position while the rubber cures in a small annular well.
This version is a bit too big to fit my hand directly, it was designed to fit over gloves and would be more comfortable if scaled down slightly. Also as printed, the material is not air-tight - it works reasonably well with a good vac pump but I think I will paint it with something (maybe more silicone rubber) to seal it better.
UPDATE (2010.10.07): I wiped it down with methylene chloride (aka dichloromethane) which fused the ABS and gave a nice glossy finish and seems to have sealed all the holes. NB this was done with gloves on, using a piece of tissue paper held in metal tweezers, in a chemical fume hood.

Adjust model to fit your hand, probably easiest by scaling the whole thing (EDIT: I scaled it to 80% and reprinted, that size [or maybe a tiny bit bigger - 85%?] works well for my hand). You may also want to adjust the mesh around the pickup end to customize it to your application. Print device and casting stand, and then cast pickup gasket in place by pouring a little bit of rubber into the ring-shaped trough in the casting stand's base plate, and placing the device into the stand while it cures.

This is a mash up between my telescopic spool holder and Chri's removable spool holder. http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

If you already have my telescopic spool holder then you need to print the dovetail mount and removable mount.
If you already have Chri's dovetail mount then you need to print off the removable mount and extension.
You will need a little bit of support for the removable mount, this can be trimmed off easily until a tight fit is achieved in the dovetail mount.
I have included Chri's dovetail mount for completeness.

title: Whoodoo Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
From the jungles of Whyst, where tree-dwelling elves have perfected the craft of whoodoo (pron: whoo, as in whoosh) making lucky thingies with skulls on them, here is a typical woodoo box found from this culture: perfect for placing small fetishes within or imprisoning troublesome will o' wisps, as this one does.
(feathers not included ;) )
I will probably eventually paint it. Hmm, maybe I should print another one so I can have one with an LED shining through and another painted. I bet it would look great in black ABS! Gotta get me summa that.
This box was printed on an UP! printer.  I used white abs plastic and a .35 mm deposition layer setting.

description.text:
Modified fan duct in Tinkercad to fit snug on the extruder and to mount a 50 mm fan.
I have the fan plugged into the 20 volt power jack on the back of the printer, I wired in a voltage step-down voltage module (ebay $4 US) that is adjustable and am running it @ approximately 14 volts.
I am finding that I get the best results when printing in "normal" mode and at .25 layer height settings.

comments.text: Functionality and fitment are no 1 priority of course ;).
comments.author: xr3dhub

comments.text: The fan does spin faster at higher voltage which of course means more airflow. I am going to adjust the voltage to the fan to 12 volts to see if makes a difference with printing. Actually I was running the fan for quite awhile without the voltage step down module, so it was running @ 19 volts! I ran the fan at that voltage for quite awhile and it held up fine for me. But these fans are inexpensive - I can get them on ebay for around $4 shipped. So it is not a huge deal if you fry one.

author: radus

title: Laser Cutter Z-Axis Parametric Alignment Jig

description.text: Customizable jig to align z-axis of a laser cutter. I had trouble getting my Z axis aligned properly with the pen and paper method for my laser cutting table. This device gave me much more accuracy and was much easier to use.

I cut this out of baltic birch but it could be easily cut out of acrylic. Your current laser doesn't have to be exactly calibrated in the Z axis to benefit from this technique. If you have a second laser that's calibrated. cut it on that device. If you only have one laser then you make due with what you have.

  • Figure out parametric variables for your laser cutter.
    -Measure nozzle width of laser (Nozzle_Dia)
    -Measure height of laser nozzle from floor to some point on the lens rings (height)
    -Measure the intervals of the table blades (basewidth > 3 * blade interval )
    -Measure the thickness of the material you will cut. (MaterialThickness)

  • Enter variable values in the OpenSCAD document.
  • Verify construction in OpenSCAD
  • Use projection option within script to generate 2D projection.
  • Compile and Render
  • Export as DXF.
    (There's an error in the OpenSCAD exporting of DXF files. You may have to correct the DXF file with a text editor or some vector graphics editor.)
  • Consider making multiple copies of target disks to fix the alignment.
  • Send the DXF file to your favorite laser cutter.
  • Construct the jig, Glue on a flat surface if you wish. Leave the platform disks unglued to be able to replace them.
  • The design has two rings to stabilize the structure but only one is probably needed.
  • Place the jig carefully under the laser. The laser platform is 3 times the material thickness higher on the z axis. So drop your z table and fire single burst to see how close to the center it comes. Adjust the mirrors as needed. Repeat until satisfied. Replace the disk as needed.
  • Congrats. I hope this helps you.
    • Note: I made the 4th fork shorter so that it could fit over the nozzle without adjusting the z table. The focus of the laser should be on the disk placed on the platform. It took me a few times to get it absolutely center but it works!

First off, I have not made or tested this. The dimensions etc are based on lessons learned from Poor Mans Quick Change Spindle thing 3855 which I did make and am currently using. I would prefer something slick looking like MakerBots spindle, so hopefully they will sell it or something. This modification of MakerBots filament spindle allows quick change for 1 lb coils of plastic. 1 lb coils slip on and off easily without unscrewing anything. This is handy for me since I have half dozen colors of plastic and switch frequently. The larger 20 inch bottom plate keeps the 1 lb coils from falling all over the place. The design also allows use of 5 lb coils, but not quick change. Simply move the vertical pieces to the inner ring of slots.
  • This design shows an 8 inch round base plate which is more stable and less likely to tip than the 4 inch turn table bearing alone.
  • One person suggested a square base since it would make more efficient use of wood.
  • An even more efficient use of wood would be an X shape that picked up the turn table holes and the rubber feet.
    • The picture shows the poor mans spindle which works well except the 16 inch base should be larger. The last image shows a 1/8 hole that can be used to lock the end of the plastic wire to the spindle if needed. p.s. Zaggo added a ring of paper around his base plate to contain the coils of plastic that tend to uncoil. see thing: 3640, image:20072. This could reduce the required size of the base plate.

Assembly instructions are virtually identical to MakerBots instructions for spindle only with the following exceptions:

  • insert vertical pieces in outer holes for 1 lb coils, inner holes for 5 lb coils

  • fasten turn table to 8 inch round, square or X shaped base.
  • for the round base attach 8 rubber feet for the best stability
  • for a square or X shaped base add 4 rubber feet

title: Prusa i3 Cooler with Bed Autolevel

description.text: This cooler will cool the J-Head extruder with a 30mm fan that I keep always on and a 40mm fan controlled by the Ramps board. It has a notch behind the 30mm fan to allow for wiring. The mounting plate for the J-Head will also accommodate a micro-servo for the bed auto-leveling feature in the latest Marlin firmware.

author: NoshTheBoss

title: Carriage pawl for Monroe model L and LA calculator

description.text: This is a carriage pawl for a Monroe models L and LA mechanical calculator. It is part of the zero-setting mechanism for the carriage, where you turn the handle one way to zero out the upper bank of digit dials, and turn the handle the other way for the lower bank. The carriage pawl specifically prevents the opposite bank from turning.

Download the files carriage-pawl-outline.dxf and carriage-pawl-reveng.scad and put them in the same directory. Then use OpenSCAD to render the object. You'll probably have to zoom in since the part is small.
The dimensions are in INCHES.
You can then export to STL (or just download carriage-pawl-reveng.stl) and send to Shapeways, for example, to make the part. Although I'm not sure any 3D printing process can render the details on this part. Make sure you make the part in METAL, because you will have to bend the tabs to get the final thing. See carriage-pawl-reveng.png (or pdf or ai or svg) for details.
One calculator requires TWO of these pawls.
This pawl will also fit on any L-series calculator (e.g. LA, LA5, etc).
The reverse-engineered technical drawing is in carriage-pawl-reveng.[ai|pdf|png|svg].

description.text: This is a straw holder for an MQ-3 alcohol sensor. The MQ-3 is used by the DrinkShield (http://www.gfxhax.com/drinkshield/). The DrinkShield is an open source breathalyzer kit. One thing that happens when people get drunk is they tend to put their lips on the MQ-3 sensor which is a bit hot. This add-on allows you to blow into the sensor without having to worry plus has the additional benefit of holding an optional straw at the end. This will work with any MQ-3 but you may have to adjust for different straw sizes.

Simply print on a makerbot.  The original source files is done in OpenScad but the STL is available as well.  Take a straw (I use ones for Malts/Shakes) and cut a few small lengths.  Those should fit in the end of the holder.  If you don't care about germs you can just blow directly into the holder itself.
Remember, drink responsibly ;)

makes the quality of the printed object better.

author: bschwan98

title: Fix for Jaycar Tech Light LED torch headlamp mount

description.text:
There are several models of Jaycar "tech light" that use a similarmounting system. It looks good in the picture on the box, but my variant wouldn't stay in horizontal beam position or tilt any higher either. I designed this fix so I can use it as a headlamp properly. Unscrew the bracket off the torch and replace with this one. This bracket also has friction locking ribs to hold position, which the tech light designer seems to have forgotten.
It took me several versions to get one where the O-ring catch posts would print and work reliably.
Take care removing the knockouts. A needle file would help.

0.275 layer height works on my 0.45mm nozzle.
2 perimeters, 50% fill or higher, 3 bottom layers and 4 top layers works on my Rostock.

title: Prusa i3 Z-axis solidifying kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This kit helps you to solidify your Prusa i3. It has 3 advantages :
• It allows you to have a more stable Z-endstop adjustment,
• You printing quality will be better if your Z-axis doesn't move anymore
• You can now speed up your printer without any side effect.
You may need some material for this modification :
16x additionnal nuts
16x additionnal rings
2x 46cm (minimal lenght) threaded rods to link the Z and Y axis
2x 46cm (minimal lenght) threaded rods in order to replace those on the Y axis.
You may also need longer screws for the top parts.

Printed fine in PLA with 200µm precision.
You don't need any support.

title: Parametric Toilet Lower Seat Hinge Bracket

description.text: I'd printed Toilet hinge http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6971 and it lasted about 12 hours. Probably because my use of Toilet Hinge Shim http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29107 made the hole centers too far apart for the toilet and put undue stress on the slightly ill fitting hinge I'd printed. I'd adjusted my Hinge Shims to address this and created this parametric model to better fit my toilet. update I've added some pin holes down half the length of the hinge to strengthen it at the neck.

You should be able to take some measurements and key them into the top half of the openscad (http://www.openscad.org/) file. Print how you see fit. The .stl file is what worked for my toilet seat. It may not work for yours.

comments.text: I may introduce 2 "pin holes" on the interior which would trick the printers into putting more material into interior at the weak points. Going to see how this first print lasts.
comments.author: creuzerm

comments.text:
Hinge broke right at the edge of the seat. Seems like there is more strain on the hinge while you are on the flat seat.
I added 3 .1mm pin holes down half the length to have the printer make more shells in the right direction for strength.
There where 17 downloads prior to my deleting the old file.

comments.text: For those that don't understand what this does, it's for leveling the bed. It mounts to the rails in your Da Vinci printer, via the two 1/2 round notches on the bottom of the part in the picture, and the same notches on the separate caps. You can then attach a test indicator, that has a mount lug on the back, into the notch on the vertical portion of the part in the picture (a test indicator like this one http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/416wetRzhyL._SX466_.jpg ). This will let you move the test indicator around on the bed, and get accurate readings of the distance from the rails.

author: GeoZMonsta

title: E3D V6 mount for ultimaker original

description.text:
This is one integrated mount for E3D V6 hot end for ultimaker original. Designed to be used with ultimaker heater cartridge but with e3d heater block.
You can use even a thermistor or thermocouple (it have holes for thermocouple transmiter)
For use the thermocouple you have to take out the thermocouple from its original encaspulate (metal) and use it without it. (maybe you have to take out also the ceramic protection inside it) It's really easy to do.
With this mount you just need:
-Metal parts from e3d v6 bowden
-100k ntc thermistor with cables (if you don't want to unmount your thermocouple)
-30mm fan
-2x 40mm fans (optional if you want symmetrical cooling)
Even it's designed to be in same place than original hot end you must readjust the XY endstops or change the trigger in the XY blocks (alan89 blocks are perfect for this)
Tested with Reptar XY blocks and the ones designed by alan89 (I use this ones). Not tested with original ones. Double fanduct for 40mm fans. The fans are 4mm high to avoid clips for heated bed. UPDATE: (14/9/2014) updated fan size for e3d heater block, old one was too close to the block. Solidworks file on youmagine

Print it in ABS if you are going to use for abs or other high temperature materials. Print by the flat face in high quality configuration.
Bearings holes are good sized but you should redrill small holes with 2.5mm drill. Don't use longer screws and don't torque them too much! It holds the hot end strong enough.

Hi
I would like to share with you one 'thing' that i've been working on in the last few days: an high speed filament pelletizer.
It is easy to manufacture, inexpensive and simple. It transforms 1 meter of filament back into pellets in ~2 seconds: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t3BcX54UkCM
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yAHYku5wsM0 It works great and I think the photos and the videos are self explanatory about how to build it and use. I'll use it to recover the filament that is rejected from my small manufacture of 3d filament. > http://www.dowire.eu Please comment.
Regards

Parts:
  • 3D printed case in ABS (3 layers and perimeters and 60% infill)
  • 1x 25mm diameter 'wolfcraft' cutter drill ref:3260 000.
  • 1x 30x30mm - 40mm long square steel tube.
  • 5x 65mm M6 threaded rods.
  • 10x M6 washers.
  • 10x M6 nuts,
  • 1x 20mm M5 bolt.
  • 1X M5 nut.
  • 1x M5 washer.
  • 1x 5x16x8 bearing.
  • 1x 10x30x10 bearing

description.text: This turbine done from 3 parts: turbine itself, that was used with some changes from thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13188 and case that consists from bottom part with motor holder and top part that covers turbine. Even with small 12V DC Motor it works perfect and powerfull enough.

Print turbine (file "Turbine 2.STL") with high quality and cover parts (files "Turbine Cover (Top).STL" and "Turbine Cover (Bottom).STL") with wall thickness 0.8 mm and normal or high quality. In top part of cover you'll need to remove thin wall inside that needed only to form flat surface on top without using support structures (you can easy see it, as it is 0.4 mm thin). You can cut it using usual paper knife for example. Assemble cover together using M3x9 (or M3x12) bolts and nuts. Turbine designed to be connected to motor adapter with single M4x30 bolt. I used 25-32 mm tension band to handle the motor inside bottom part of cover. I also attached adapter for motor that I have in file "Motor Gear Connector (Sliced) - 2.STL". Print two parts and connect together with two M3x16 bolts and nuts, put inside single M4 nut to be used for turbine connection. Turbine top cover has end that fit just fine 30 mm pipe adapter designed here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39745 and was done to be used together with it (take some time to see how and where it can be used together with this adapter). Note: In some .STL files you'll need to flip Y-Z planes to place details correct on printing table. Use free for your needs! ;)

author: Order_3D

description.text: dd

Customizable Hith Joint (CSG version) (library)
This is an improved version of
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:387292
This improved model can start the teeth not just at the center but also at a polygon of choosable radius. Meaning one can create thin walled tube couplings that are radially self centering (Such couplings are often found in Mountainbike axles).
The interpenetration depth of the teeth can be limited with the flatlimit parameter.

hirthaxle(l,d,dbore,n,beta,delta,flatlimit)
hirthtube(l,d,dbore,n,beta,delta,flatlimit)
"axle"-postfix: all teeth converge to the center
"tube"-postfix: all teeth emerge from the polygon inscribed into the bore diameter

description.header: Convinience functions that make the coupling printeable upside down:
description.text:
supportlesshirthaxle(l,d,dbore,n,beta,delta,flatlimit)
supportlesshirthtube(l,d,dbore,n,beta,delta,flatlimit)
"supportless"-prefix: optimized for upside down supportless printability

hirth(l,d,dbore,dpolygon,n,beta,delta,flatlimit,inlimit)
rawhirth(beta,delta,n,dpolygon,flatlimit,inlimit)
Notes regarding the first design:
  • The parametric interdependencies behave a little different in this model!
  • Using volumetric CSG descriptions turns out to be a lot easier than triangle vertex juggling.

One of our lighting guys asked me if I could 3-D print color-coded fader pads to help him keep track of different setups for different shows in low light. I created a simple copy of the original fader with TinkerCAD, and printed them in fluorescent plastic.  
(modeled for a fader with a 5mm x 1mm slider)
This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18115. This design fits around the printer.

This is made from 3/4 Schedule 40 PVC. Get it from your big box home improvement store. There are no exact measurements here. You will need 6 90° elbows and 2 tee joints. Use 6 lengths of PVC joined by 4 elbows at the corners and the tee joints on each side. Out of the tee joints comes two more lengths with the other two elbows. Then there is one more length at the top. I would not glue anything. It is very sturdy and I like mine to come apart. My particular build was about $10 and took around 12' of PVC. YMMV.

2D gimbal for:

Mad soldering skills

GoPro Hero 3(+) specific:

Plastic tubing to protect exposed FC200 jack

description.text:
This case will keep the circuit board inside the car alarm and an engine that generates the power to send the signal to the receiver.
The mechanical force applied to generate electricity.

"Esta carcasa podrá mantener en su interior la placa electrónica de la alarma del automóvil y un motor que generara la energía para mandar la señal al receptor.
La fuerza mecánica aplicada generara electricidad"

Yet another base plate for your Raspberry Pi. Doesn't do anything special; just keeps the board elevated and provides some more convenient mounting holes.  
Outer dimensions are 64mm by 96mm - or 8 by 12 LEGO studs. The holes in the corners are sized and aligned to press snugly onto 1x1 LEGO pieces. (A little filing may be necessary to make the fit smooth.) Of course, they'd work fine with screws and washers too.
I printed mine in clear PLA on my Printrbot Simple. 3 perimeters, 0.15mm layer height, 0.2 hexagonal infill.

title: Parametric Link Generator for Mechanisms and Frames

description.text:
These are OpenSCAD modules to generate links based on a user-provided set of dimensions.  Each link includes holes at the ends for attaching to other links using pins.  
I use these modules to quickly create links for frames and mechanisms.

Use or Include "Links.scad" in your OpenSCAD file.  
link_solid(length, width, thickness, hole_radius) generates a solid link with a hole at each end.  Set hole_radius to 0 for no holes.
link_lite(length, width, thickness, hole_radius, centersegs) generates a link with cutouts evenly distributed along the length.  The cutouts reduce weight and make for faster 3D printing.  Parameter centersegs specifies the number of cutouts.

I used natural PLA but ABS might be better. It is not under any significant load. It shouldn't get excessively hot.  
This seems to fall outside the currently defined categories :)

Hey internet!
We just bought some NinjaFlex and wanted to make some phone cases. Only problem was these cases are more for rigid filament. We added a bridge to the top to allow the flexible case to wrap around the phone. We are printing one right now! Pics to come
We haven't added a head phone jack yet but plan to in the near future.

Flexible filament cant be printed at the same speeds as PLA. Too fast and the filament will buckle and spill out into the extruder assembly. Plrint at about 225C and 30mm/s,
No supports. No raft.

1) Edit the "User-defined values" values to meet your needs. Configure both the board and screw properties if necessary.

description.text: I always put 2 teaspoons of sugar into my tea. This is a pain, since you have to either tear open two little packets of sugar, or else get a spoon for measuring it out. This device makes the whole ordeal go away, dispensing two teaspoons into your cup withy a flick of the wrist. Threads onto a standard Anchor Hocking-type glass sugar dispenser body, available e.g., at Smart & Final, Wal-Mart, or, on the internet, e.g., here: http://www.retroplanet.com/PROD/10090

1. Obtain a sugar dispenser as described above. Discard the metal cap, keeping only the glass body. 2. Print the "cap" portion of the design. 3. Print the "spout" portion of the design. 4. Clean up the printed parts as needed. The spout should fit tightly into the square hole in the cap. The cap should thread on to the glass sugar dispenser with a snug fit. 5. Glue the spout into the cap, using epoxy, CA-type adhesive (e.g., Krazy Glue), or acrylic cement (if you printed in ABS). You're done! To use, fill the glass thing with sugar, and put the cap on. To dispense, turn the whole unit upside down (so the spout fills with sugar), then right-side-up again (so the sugar pours out of the spout into your cup. It's easy, but you may want to practice over the sink!

title: Filament Pass-Through (Parametric) using Old Wiper Blades as a Seal
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: a.k.a. Windshield Wiper Seal (Parametric) This thing holds pieces of used windshield wiper blade rubber together in order to cover a gap in a channel while still permitting something to go through it. This is useful if you have a channel at the top of a ventilated case through which you pass filament. It's fully parametric (18 parameters), very well commented, and each to configure. You can define the wiper blade properties including overlap, object properties including size and number of mounting holes, and screw and bracket properties. The default values (and STL) are suitable for a filament guide and pass-through for a Printrbot LC enclosure, with a channel width of about 5.25 inches (134mm), and fastened with six M3 screws. The default support material angle is 45 degrees, and includes a 0.4mm solid layer inside the holes (to be drilled out) for better hole printing. I use this as part of my parametric printer enclosure, which is available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39787

1) Take apart an old windshield wiper and remove the rubber blade. (You can probably get the local service station to give you one they replace.)  Measure the blade properties and add them to the User-defined values section. 
2a) You'll probably need to run the STL through netfabb to clean it up. I still need to tweak the OpenSCAD file a bit to try to avoid those. 
2b) Print (diagonally will probably get you the longest channel) 
3) Cut wiper blade rubber to size, and install as shows in the pictures. The OpenSCAD file echos out precisely how long to cut the blades, as well as some other helpful information.

title: Printer Enclosure Cut List (Parametric)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This parametric OpenSCAD file will help you make a simple and easy-to-build printer case. The build output includes a full cut list and includes an estimate of the enclosed volume so you can choose an appropriate ventilation system, if desired. The default units are in inches, but you can use whatever you want because this won't actually get printed. As an example, the cut list output looks something like this:
ECHO: "Cut grooves in frame structure to 0.1875 deep."
ECHO: "Cut windows a hair small so fit is not too snug."
ECHO: "Frame components are organized Left, Right, Bottom, Top."
ECHO: "Enclosure is about 2.20269 cubic feet."
ECHO: "Table", [16, 19, 0.75]
ECHO: "Front Frame", [15.75, 0.75, 0.75], "", "Back"
ECHO: "Front Frame", [15.75, 0.75, 0.75], "", "Back"
ECHO: "Front Frame", [14.5, 0.75, 0.75], "", ""
...(etc.)...

Change "User-defined values" to define the maximum interior size your printer needs to operate. (e.g. move to the maximums and minimums of each axis. Then render with F5. Copy and paste all the echo output for a complete cut list, including "glass" (plastic, hardboard, etc) panels. The frame pieces in the cut list include "Back" and/or "Front", which indicates where the grooves belong for adding the panels. The grooves are always either on one side or on two adjacent sides (and one piece gets no grooves), but never on opposite sides. You will probably need to chisel a few small portions so that the groove goes all the way around. For wood to build the case, go to your local lumber yard and ask for moulding or trim with a square profile, or mill it yourself if you have the tools. (If you don't have a table saw, you'll probably need to get someone to cut the grooves for you so you can add the panels.) The one in the photo was milled from reclaimed maple board. Square profile molding probably isn't so common that you'll find it at a large home center (like Lowes), but lumber yards should have it or be able to get it. I used wood glue alone for the front, back, and door frames, and used wood screws (with no glue) for the four pieces that connect the front and back so that it can be collapsed if necessary. If you do this, be sure to pre-drill the holes because you're going into end grain and you don't want it to split. Because the glue is end-to-edge grain, probably won't hold up well to a lot of abuse. If you need something sturdier, consider using a wooden dowel, which would still allow you to drill out the holes for the wood screws like I have it. The "glass" panels are clear acrylic sheet, cut to size on a table saw, and the bottom is a bit of 3/4" plywood reclaimed from a server box pallet. I'm venting the case, so I mounted the door so it was pretty close on the top and right, and filled the hinged gap with insulation. This leaves a gap at the bottom front where fresh air can be sucked in. You may want to include these options, as well:
  • Vertical Board Anchor (to stabilize feet): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39778
  • Case Lid Position Guide (to stabilize lid): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39780
  • Tube Adapter Flange with Optional Grating (for venting): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38813
  • Cable Plug Hole Cover (for passing through wires): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38819
  • Filament Pass-Through: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39782
  • Knob with Latch: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39974

description.text:
A cable chain bottom link which screws onto the printrbot left Z motor mount.
This is for the basic plastic version with my improved stepper mounts/bases.

You should be able to use two longer screws into the stepper to attach it.
The chain will be at the front left.
If you don't have my stepper mounts you can probably screw into the stepper but I would recommend the more stable bases - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28557
I plan to use the chain to go to the Z-stage but not to the extruder. If you want to go to the extruder you need to use a different part set - look in the SU file. My chain has the two movable bottom links reversed compared to the rest.

This is the second revision of the Bulldog Clip Extruder R1 found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:373523
This is an extruder which uses a bulldog clip in the place of the spring.
Compatibility:
Jhead mount, Bowden, E3d(NEW)
(Please email me at [email protected] if you would like to request for me to make this compatible for your system.)
Updates:
-Added a new bottom piece for E3d. I realised that the E3d slot was slightly different from Jhead, so I have modified to include E3d compatibility
-created a little bit more space near the ball bearing to ensure that it 'pinches' the filament harder
-Added a slot on the arm so that it will avoid the centre piece on the stepper.
I designed this with a few things in mind:
1) it should be easy to print and build (uses only 6 screws, a 623 bearing, and a 3/4" bulldog clip, each of which are easily obtainable)
2) it should be durable (my previous design, the rubberband extruder, required occasional replacement of rubberbands. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:206211 )
3) it should have a guide from below the drive gear to support the use of flexible filaments.
4) should be easy to maintain (it features an open design which reduces the need to disaassemble the for most maintenance issues. However should you require to disassemble it, you only need to remove a maximum of 6 screws)
5) it should make loading and unloading of filament to be easy (press to release the idler bearing, insert filament from the top.)
Parts required:
1) 4 M3X25 screws
2) 2 M4 screws to mount the extruder to your X carriage
3) a Mk8 or Mk7 drive gear, easily obtainable on Ebay or Aliexpress. use the files accordingly depending on which extruder you choose.
4) a 623 bearing, easily available on Ebay or Aliexpress.
5) a 3/4" bulldog clip.
mount for a sirius satellite receiver with a base that fits in a cup holder in the center console of a 2007 Ford 500
designed in openscad
Simple LED Holder to mount two 5mm LEDs to shine down on the print bed of a PrintrBot LC

After mounting a 40mm fan to my PrintrBot LC, it was hard to see the printed item. I created this simple LED Holder to mount two 5mm LEDs to shine down on the print bed. Tools:
3D Printer
Soldering Iron
Heat Gun
Wire strippers
Screw Driver
Wire Cutters Parts List:
(2) 5mm High-Brightness White LED (2-Pack), http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=3060980
(1) Deans Micro Connector, http://www.rpphobby.com/product_p/wsd1222.htm
(1) 220 ohm 1/4W Resistor, http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=2062340
(1) Power connector, i.e., Molex Power Cable (cut off the black connector), http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=3780246 Solder
Shrink Tube
Wire The LED Holder will fit snugly between the hex nuts on the PrintrBot LC and uses the existing #6-32 screws. Remove the two lower screws and washers, put the holder in the place of the washers and reinstall the two screws. I used a Micro Deans connector as a disconnect at the print head. The resistor value assumes connection to +12V and the specs of the RadioShack white LEDS (FW current: 25mA, FW supply: 3.3V). If you are using a different LED or power source, go here for a simple resistor calculator: http://led.linear1.org/led.wiz I used a PC power connector to get the 12V to power the LEDs from one of the available connectors on the PC power supply.

description.text: Keeps those cards in slick sleeves from sliding around the table. Now sized to hold a Commander deck (aka EDH, Eternal Dragon Highlander) composed of 100 cards in sleeves. Still printable on a Thing-O-Matic.

Just in time for those New Years Eve MtG games that will last from 2012 all the way to 2013.
  • Print.
  • Trim or sand (if necessary.)
  • Play.
    • By popular demand. Plus, I wanted one for myself. Including the .blend file this time so you guys can have at it.
    Update- added .stl and .gcode for cardholder02, which thickens the sides by 5mm to make them stronger (the initial version broke in my backpack.) The 02 gcode also reduced my flow rate slightly, and was done with an extra shell for added strength. Though I do recommend compiling from the .stl instead of printing my .gcode, since every Thing-O-Matic is different.
    Version 02 is still printable on a Thing-O-Matic, though you'll probably need the build plate instead of the conveyor belt. Finished dimensions are 98mm W x 109mm D by 69mm H.

author: NeoTech76

title: Fan Guard and Shroud for Replicator Dual-Extruder

description.text:
Clive the Makerbot wanted to grow a mustache, but I wanted him to have a fan shroud. We compromised by using Tinkercad and NetFabb to mash together CrazyJaw's Fan Guards with ColinBB's Dual Extruder Fan Shroud. Then Clive straight up printed himself CrazyJaw's MonseÃ±or Replicator Mustache. 
Clive looks quite dapper and his air is headed in the right direction.

comments.text: Someone correct me if I'm wrong but after installing the shroud I took a better look and don't see any outlet for the air the fans pull in. I know the goal is to keep air off the print but will this total encapsulation affect the extruders at all? It seems that they would pull more cool air if they have an outlet to reduce back pressure.
comments.author: yournamehere18

description.text: It's a beautiful body with the head knocked off. I used my camera and uploaded the images into the PC version of 123D Catch when I got home. Pretty good results.
Should 3D print rather well.

comments.text:
Now we might add a head of our own. Moowah. Ha. Ha.

comments.text: That's one of the things that the folks at the Metropolitan Museum of Art hoped would happen. They were like, "There are all these broken heads, arms, noses and other parts that need fixing." Go for it!
